RockPy.Measurements.backfield module¶

class RockPy.Measurements.backfield.Backfield(sample_obj, mtype, mfile, machine, **options)¶

Bases: RockPy.Measurements.base.Measurement

A Backfield Curve can give information on:

Bcr: the remanence coercivity

S300: \((1 - (M_{300mT} /M_{rs})) / 2\)

Bcr is determined by finding the intersection of the linear interpolated measurement data with the axis representing zero-magnetization. For the calculation of S300, the initial magnetization is used as an approximation of the saturation remanence \(M_{rs}\) and the magnetization at 300mT \(M_{300mT}\) is determined by linear interpolation of measured data.

bcr¶

returns the bcr value if already calculated, calls calculate_bcr if not yet calculated :return:

calculate_bcr()¶

calculates Bcr from linear interpolation between two points closest to mag = o

Bcr is the field needed to demagnetize the saturation remanence

Returns:float calculated bcr value
calculate_s300()¶

S300: :math:`(1 - (M_{300mT} /M_{rs})) / 2

Returns:result
format_vftb()¶

formats the output from vftb to measurement. data :return:

plt_backfield()¶
result_bcr(recalc=False)¶

calculates \(B_{cr}\) :param recalc: :return:

vftb_file = 'test_data/MUCVFTB_test2.coe'
sample = Sample(name='vftb_test_sample')
M = sample.add_measurement(mtype='backfield', mfile=vftb_file, machine='vftb')

M.calculate_bcr()
print M.bcr

>>> -0.0202307972682

RockPy.Measurements.base module¶

class RockPy.Measurements.base.Measurement(sample_obj, mtype, mfile, machine, **options)¶

Bases: object

add_treatment(ttype, tvalue, comment='')¶
calc_all(**parameter)¶
calc_generic(**parameter)¶

helper function actual calculation of the result

Returns:
calc_result(parameter={}, recalc=False, force_caller=None)¶

Helper function: Calls any calculate_* function, but checks first:

  1. does this calculation method exist

  2. has it been calculated before |- NO : calculate the result |- YES: are given parameters equal to previous calculation parameters

    |- NO : calculate result with new parameters |- YES: return previous result

Parameters:
  • parameter – dict dictionary with parameters needed for calculation
  • caller – calling function name without calculate_
  • force_caller – not dynamically retrieved caller name.
Returns:
calculate_generic(**parameter)¶

actual calculation of the result

Returns:
check_parameters(caller, parameter)¶

Checks if previous calculation used the same parameters, if yes returns the previous calculation if no calculates with new parameters :param caller: str

name of calling function (‘result_generic’ should be given as ‘result’)
Parameters:parameter –
Returns:
compare_parameters(caller, parameter, recalc)¶

checks if given parameter[key] is None and replaces it with standard parameter or calculation_parameters.

e.g. calculation_generic(A=1, B=2)
calculation_generic() # will calculate with A=1, B=2 calculation_generic(A=3) # will calculate with A=3, B=2 calculation_generic(A=2, recalc=True) # will calculate with A=2 B=standard_parameter[‘B’]
Parameters:
  • caller – str name of calling function (‘result_generic’ should be given as ‘generic’)
  • parameter – Parameters to check
  • recalc – Boolean True if forced recalculation, False if not
Returns:
generic¶

helper function that returns the value for a given statistical method. If result not available will calculate it with standard parameters

implemented = None¶

initialize parameters

import_data(rtn_raw_data=None, **options)¶

Importing the data from dfile and machine :param rtn_raw_data: :param options: :return:

classmethod inheritors()¶
result_generic(recalc=False)¶

Generic for for result implementation. Every calculation of result should be in the self.results data structure before calculation. It should then be tested if a value for it exists, and if not it should be created by calling _calculate_result_(result_name).

RockPy.Measurements.thellier module¶

calc_all(**parameter)¶
calculate_b_anc(**parameter)¶
calculate_beta(**parameter)¶
:math`eta` is a measure of the relative data scatter around the best-fit line and is the ratio of the standard error of the slope to the absolute value of the slope (Coe et al., 1978)

rac{sigma_b}{|b|}

param parameters:
 
return:
calculate_delta_x_dash(**parameter)¶

∆x0 and ∆y0 are TRM and NRM lengths of the best-ﬁt line on the Arai plot, respectively (Figure 1).

calculate_delta_y_dash(**parameter)¶

∆x0 and ∆y0 are TRM and NRM lengths of the best-ﬁt line on the Arai plot, respectively (Figure 1).

calculate_f(**parameter)¶

The remanence fraction, f, was defined by Coe et al. (1978) as:

\[f = \frac{\Delta y^T}{y_0}\]

where \(\Delta y^T\) is the length of the NRM/TRM segment used in the slope calculation.

Parameters:parameter –
Returns:
calculate_f_vds(**parameter)¶

NRM fraction used for the best-fit on an Arai diagram calculated as a vector difference sum (Tauxe and Staudigel, 2004).

\[f_{VDS}=\]

rac{Delta{y’}}{VDS}

param parameter:
 
return:
calculate_frac(**parameter)¶

NRM fraction used for the best-fit on an Arai diagram determined entirely by vector difference sum calculation (Shaar and Tauxe, 2013).

\[FRAC=\]

rac{sumlimits_{i=start}^{end-1}{ left|mathbf{NRM}_{i+1}-mathbf{NRM}_{i} ight| }}{VDS}

param parameter:
 
return:
calculate_g(**parameter)¶

Gap factor: A measure of the gap between the points in the chosen segment of the Arai plot and the least-squares line. ‘g’ approaches (n-2)/(n-1) (close to unity) as the points are evenly distributed.

calculate_gap_max(**parameter)¶

The gap factor defined above is measure of the average Arai plot point spacing and may not represent extremes of spacing. To account for this Shaar and Tauxe (2013)) proposed \(GAP extrm{-}MAX\), which is the maximum gap between two points determined by vector arithmetic.

\[GAP extrm{-}MAX=\]

rac{max{{left|mathbf{NRM}_{i+1}-mathbf{NRM}_{i} ight|}}_{i=start, ldots, end-1}}{sumlimits_{i=start}^{end-1}{left|mathbf{NRM}_{i+1}-mathbf{NRM}_{i} ight|}} ]

return:
calculate_q(**parameter)¶

The quality factor (\(q\)) is a measure of the overall quality of the paleointensity estimate and combines the relative scatter of the best-fit line, the NRM fraction and the gap factor (Coe et al., 1978).

\[q=\]

rac{left|b ight|fg}{sigma_b}= rac{fg}{eta}

param parameter:
 
return:
calculate_sigma_b_anc(**parameter)¶
calculate_slope(**parameter)¶

calculates the least squares slope for the specified temperature interval

Parameters:parameter –
calculate_vd(**parameter)¶

Vector differences :param parameter: :return:

calculate_vds(**parameter)¶

The vector difference sum of the entire NRM vector \(($$\mathbf{NRM}$$)\).

\[[ VDS=\left|\mathbf{NRM}_{n_{max}}\]

ight|+sumlimits_{i=1}^{n_{max}-1}{left|mathbf{NRM}_{i+1}-mathbf{NRM}_{i} ight|}

where :math:`left|mathbf{NRM}_{i}

ight|` denotes the length of the NRM vector at the \(i^{th}\) step.

param parameter:
 
return:
calculate_w(**parameter)¶

Weighting factor of Prévot et al. (1985). It is calculated by:

\[w=\]

ac{q}{sqrt{n-2}}

Originally it is :math:`w=

rac{fg}{s}`, where \(s^2\) is given by:

\[s^2=2+\]

rac{2sumlimits_{i=start}^{end}{(x_i-ar{x})(y_i-ar{y})}}{left( sumlimits_{i=start}^{end}{(x_i-ar{x})^{ rac{1}{2}}} sumlimits_{i=start}^{end}{(y_i-ar{y})^2} ight)^2}

It can be noted, however, that \(w\) can be more readily calculated as:

\[w=\]

ac{q}{sqrt{n-2}}

param parameter:
 
return:
calculate_x_dash(**parameter)¶

\(x_0 and :math:`y_0\) the x and y points on the Arai plot projected on to the best-ﬁt line. These are used to calculate the NRM fraction and the length of the best-ﬁt line among other parameters. There are multiple ways of calculating \(x_0 and :math:`y_0\), below is one example.

..math:

x_i’ =

rac{1}{2} left( x_i + rac{y_i - Y_{int}}{b}

param parameter:
 
return:
calculate_y_dash(**parameter)¶

\(x_0 and :math:`y_0\) the x and y points on the Arai plot projected on to the best-ﬁt line. These are used to calculate the NRM fraction and the length of the best-ﬁt line among other parameters. There are multiple ways of calculating \(x_0 and :math:`y_0\), below is one example.

..math:

y_i’ =

rac{1}{2} left( x_i + rac{y_i - Y_{int}}{b}

param parameter:
 
return:
